item.title: Desperate for a striker, N'Golo Kante compromised for Jorginho and no Plan B… why Maurizio Sarri and Chelsea are searching for answers amid sub-par 'Sarriball'
item.description: MATT BARLOW: Losing twice to Spurs inside seven weeks at Wembley is no Chelsea fan's idea of a having a good time and the manager is searching for answers.
item.content:encoded:
Maurizio Sarri arrived at Chelsea promising fun and after a season of Antonio Conte's thunderous moods it was a message well received.

Eden Hazard perked up immediately as the campaign opened with an unbeaten run of 18 games in all competitions and there was even a time, albeit brief, when it seemed he might solve the Alvaro Morata puzzle.

There was lots to like about Sarriball and its eccentric creator, lost in his own world of tactical analysis, tobacco and superstition.

Then came the humbling at the hands of Tottenham in November and the impetus has faded, goals have dried up and the arm of Sarri's fun-o-meter swung back from the image of happy Hazard to the glum face of Morata.

Not a lot is wrong. Chelsea are tight at the back and can dominate in midfield, but at the very top not a lot needs to be wrong and losing twice to Spurs inside seven weeks at Wembley is no Chelsea fan's idea of a having a good time and the manager is searching for answers.


LACK OF A STRIKER

This time last year Conte, the manager who ostracised Diego Costa, was in a flap about signing a centre forward, having quickly decided Morata, the £68million then-record signing, was not the answer.

Eventually, Olivier Giroud arrived but 12 months on and Sarri wants a new man up front. How he must look at Tottenham and long for Harry Kane when his own team cannot convert comfortable possession into goal threat.

Hazard through the centre denies Chelsea their best player: Hazard the wide attacker, who can score and create from the spaces he finds on the left.

Willian and Pedro, even when fit and fresh, cannot do what Hazard does in the wide areas. Callum Hudson-Odoi has caught the eye but what's the point of an old fashioned winger whipping crosses into the box if there's no-one with a goal scorer's instinct on the end?

With Hazard up front, dropping short for the ball, there is no threat in behind which, arguably, Chelsea have lacked since Costa's exit.

Conte craved a technical centre forward, who could hold up the ball, bring others into play and still offer aerial presence and weigh in with goals. So does Sarri.

Conte wanted Gonzalo Higuain. So does Sarri. Higuain is still very expensive and now 31. The deal makes little business sense.

THE MIDFIELD CONUNDRUM

NGolo Kante is a midfielder made for English football. Quick with endless stamina, a low centre of gravity and an ability to read the game.

He can cover the miles and prey on mistakes forced by the hustle and bustle. He wins the ball and moves it quickly; a turnover specialist.

He was the secret behind the Leicester miracle, helped Chelsea to the title and France to the World Cup.

He has signed a new five-year contract, thought to be worth £290,000 a week and yet he does not fit smoothly into Sarri's three-man midfield.

It's hard to believe no-one saw this one coming. Jorginho is so crucial to Sarriball that it was the one summer signing he demanded before taking the job.

In this tactical system, he is the pivotal player, orchestrating the tempo and rhythm on the ball.

Kante is not a holding midfielder, he cannot play this position. He is a ball-winning midfielder and needs licence to run.

Conte soon realised he was wasted, sitting in front of the centre-halves when he switched from 4-2-3-1 to 3-4-3, the key moment in 2016-17.

Chelsea fixtures

Premier League unless stated

Saturday Newcastle (H)

January 19 Arsenal (A)

January 24 Tottenham (H) Carabao Cup semi-final, second leg

January 26/27 Sheffield Wednesday or Luton (H) FA Cup fourth round

January 30 Bournemouth (A)

February 2 Huddersfield (H)

He can operate perfectly well on the right side of Sarri's midfield trio and sometimes even look good but this role does not maximise his unique talents.

No longer does everyone leave every Chelsea game thinking: Wow, Kante…

With Hazard through the centre and Kante on the right, they are without their two best players. Jorginho, meanwhile, has become too easy to neutralise and has not been able to justify this decision to compromise Kante.

To get the best from Kante, the manager would have to abandon the system to which he is wed. If Chelsea truly believed in Sarriball they would have sold him in the summer to Paris Saint-Germain and used the millions to buy players who fit the system.

TURN UP THE PACE

During the early part of the season when results were going well, it was the tempo which concerned Sarri. He wanted the ball moving more quickly. He demanded one-touch and two-touch football and movement from his team.

Chelsea have high-quality players. They soon picked it up. But opponents have reacted to combat the threat.

They sit back, congest key areas, crowd Sarri's team and then try to damage them on the counter-attack.

Leicester and Wolves, quick on the break, beat them. Tottenham's penalty at Wembley came from a long ball over the top.

Losing Pedro to injury didn't help. Pedro is fast and direct and his powers may be fading but he still offers Sarri something his other strikers don't.

Also, Chelsea do not have the speed at full back when others do. Cesar Azpilicueta was ideal for Conte's back three. Marcos Alonso, a terrific wing-back. Neither fit quite so perfectly into Sarri's plans.

At the same time, fatigue is setting in, testing Sarri's desire to operate with a small core of first-team players, resisting any major squad rotation, even in the early stages of the Europa League and the Carabao Cup.

The development stages of a successful foreign coach arriving in the Premier League often follows a similar theme.

They will arrive and demand more running and intensity, then realise all this high-intensity running around in the world's most competitive league and its demanding fixture fixtures is tiring, and then complain about the gruelling schedule and demand more players.

NO PLAN B

Perhaps most noticeable in the goalless draw against Southampton when Ralph Hasenhuttl came to Stamford Bridge with a plan to bore Chelsea into submission.

Sarri's team had 72 per cent of possession and 17 shots but only six on target. The numbers were similar at Spurs in the Carabao Cup. Only Hazard's individuality lifted Chelsea above the ordinary at Watford on Boxing Day.

As more teams - especially those unwilling to go toe-to-toe at football - adopted this tactical plan, scoring has become a problem for Chelsea.

Sarri said he was satisfied up to the last 20 metres of the pitch against Saints but the last 20 metres is the important bit.

Chelsea have failed to find the net in three of their last six games and the manager is behaving as if he thinks he does not have the solution inside his squad.

Still, he keeps plugging away with his way of playing.

Liverpool finished against Manchester City with Virgil van Dijk at centre-forward. When all else fails, go long to the biggest man you have. When you're crowded out, the most obvious alternatives are set-pieces and aerial attack.

But Sarri seems so devoted to his system he has shown no hint of a willingness to change.

Maybe a new centre forward would help. Maybe Higuain can provide the technical presence and score enough goals to make a difference. Maybe it would offer Hazard a little more freedom. Maybe it would lift the manager.

Sarriball, however, is a collective philosophy. Maybe it will need more than a new centre forward before it is remodelled successfully for the Premier League.
item.dc:abstract: MATT BARLOW: There was lots to like about Sarriball and its eccentric creator, lost in his own world of tactical analysis, tobacco and superstition. Then came the humbling at the hands of Tottenham in November and the impetus has faded, goals have dried up and the arm of Sarri's fun-o-meter swung back from the image of happy Hazard to the glum face of Morata. Not a lot is wrong. Chelsea are tight at the back and can dominate in midfield, but at the very top not a lot needs to be wrong and losing twice to Spurs inside seven weeks at Wembley is no Chelsea fan's idea of a having a good time and the manager is searching for answers.

item.title: Cameron Bancroft back with a bang as he hits first half-century for Perth Scorchers since returning from ball-tampering suspension
item.description: Cameron Bancroft hit his first half-century since returning from a nine-month ban to help the Perth Scorchers beat Melbourne Stars by six wickets in the Big Bash.
item.content:encoded:
Cameron Bancroft hit his first half-century since returning from a nine-month ban to help Perth Scorchers beat Melbourne Stars by six wickets in the Big Bash.

The Scorchers opener, who received a nine-month suspension for ball tampering while playing for Australia, made 59 off 42 balls before he was stumped by Seb Gotch off the bowling of Liam Bowe.

Bancroft was caught using sandpaper to alter the condition of the ball against South Africa in Cape Town in March.


The 26-year-old returned to action 10 days ago and was playing his fourth match as he attempts to resurrect his career.

His haul in the night match at Melbourne Cricket Ground included four fours and two maximums as the Scorchers successfully chased the Stars' score of 146 for six with 14 balls to spare.

All-rounder David Willey also contributed to the away team's victory by claiming the crucial wicket of Stars top scorer Ben Dunk, who was caught by Ashton Agar for 62.

Willey's fellow England international Liam Plunkett later caught and bowled Bancroft's opening partner Michael Klinger for 29 but he finished on the losing side having taken one for 35 from 3.4 overs.

item.title: Real Madrid's new £22m signing Brahim Diaz set for debut against Leganes in Copa del Rey last 16
item.description: PETE JENSON: But he will do so from the bench because Real Madrid's disastrous league form means as few changes as possible will be made to the starting line-up for the Cup game.
item.content:encoded:
Nineteen-year-old Brahim Diaz is set to make Real Madrid his debut just 48 hours after signing his €3.5million a season, six-and-a-half year contract.

But he will do so from the bench because Real Madrid's disastrous league form means as few changes as possible will be made to the starting line-up for the Cup game.

Madrid face Leganes in the last-16 of Spain's Copa del Rey and Wednesday night's home leg has taken on increased importance after the club fell 10 points behind Barcelona in the league at the weekend, losing 2-0 to Real Sociedad.


That limits coach Santiago Solari's freedom to experiment and give minutes to the former City teenager but he will feature at some point as Madrid look to find away to lift their supporters.

Solari said his appearance was 'pending paperwork' but the lowest gate of the season is expected thanks to the late kick-off (21.30 local time), the team's poor league form, and the game being a first leg.

Diaz has only trained once with his new team-mates but he has impressed them with the confident nature of his presentation on Monday and his first session on Tuesday.

He looks ready for minutes and he will get them against a Leganes side looking to repeat the feat of knocking Real Madrid out of the cup.

The defeat last season was an embarrassment to Madrid and spelled the beginning of the end for Zinedine Zidane.

The French coach began to sense that, save the big Champions League games, he was now unable to motivate the players. And the club's board - sensing the same thing - began pondering his end of season departure.

Leganes are coached by former Southampton manager Mauricio Pellegrini and have former Saints striker Guido Carillo in their ranks. But the Argentine centre-forward could be rested as Danish striker Maritn Braithwaite makes his debut on loan from Middlesbrough.

item.title: Callum Hudson-Odoi has asked Chelsea team-mate Antonio Rudiger for advice on playing in Germany as Bayern Munich close in
item.description: Talented Chelsea youngster Callum Hudson-Odoi has sought the advice of team-mate Antonio Rudiger about what it is like to play in Germany, the defender has revealed.
item.content:encoded:
Talented Chelsea youngster Callum Hudson-Odoi has sought the advice of team-mate Antonio Rudiger about what it is like to play in Germany, the defender has revealed.

Bayern Munich are continuing to pursue a move for Hudson-Odoi in January having initially seen their efforts rebuffed.

But speaking to reporters after defeat by Tottenham on Tuesday, Rudiger revealed the 18-year-old is trying to do his research on life in the Bundesliga, suggesting a move is edging closer.


'He asked me about Germany,' Rudiger said after the 1-0 Carabao Cup loss at Wembley.

'It was a general question from him. He is still young, I can advise him, but at the end of the day he decides about his future.

'You can see it from both sides. He can develop here but he can develop in Germany as well — and don't forget Bayern Munich are also a big club. For his future, I wish him all the best but I just wish he stays with us.'

The move to Bayern is gathering pace after the Bundesliga champions matched Chelsea's £35million valuation on Tuesday.

Game-time has been a big factor for the player and given the success of Englishman Jadon Sancho at Borussia Dortmund, he finds himself weighing up whether life in Germany can help kick-start his career.

So far, Hudson-Odoi has struggled for game time at Chelsea but was handed a start in the Carabao Cup semi-final on Tuesday night.

When he does play he makes an impact, as shown when he secured assists for both goals in the recent 2-0 FA Cup win over Nottingham Forest.

The £58m summer arrival of Christian Pulisic from Dortmund is another factor which could push Hudson-Odoi to Bavaria but the club are keen to keep him at Stamford Bridge with boss Maurizio Sarri trying to give him more minutes in a bid to convince him to stay.

The player has just 18 months left on his deal and should he remain at the club this month, Chelsea would be under mounting pressure to cash in if he does not commit his future.

Bayern announced the signing of French right back Benjamin Pavard on Wednesday but sporting director Hasan Salihamidzic also confirmed the club's concrete interest in the Chelsea starlet.

'What I can say: we like the player and take a great interest in signing him. We'll see about the rest,' he said at the unveiling of Pavard.

'We must identify those players which can improve us. Callum has unbelievable qualities in the dribbling, he has the pace and skills. We want to sign him.'

item.title: Manchester United midfielder Ethan Hamilton in talks over Rochdale loan
item.description: Manchester United midfielder Ethan Hamilton is in talks over a loan move to League One Rochdale. The 20-year-old Scot has been a regular in Ricky Sbragia's U23 side.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester United midfielder Ethan Hamilton is in talks over a loan move to League One Rochdale.

The 20-year-old Scot has been a regular in Ricky Sbragia's U23 side and has had interest from Scottish Premiership clubs.

However, United see a spell at League One Rochdale, under manager Keith Hill, as being good for his football education.


Hamilton can also play as a left wing back and has trained with United's first team.

He was called up by Jose Mourinho to replace Paul Pogba against Huddersfield Town in the squad last season when the Frenchman picked up an injury.

United coach Kieran McKenna said: 'With his attitude, it could certainly carry him very far in his career.'

Rochdale had also expressed interest in United defender Regan Poole, as have Newport County.

United, meanwhile, are discussing a move for Villarreal's 16-year-old left-back Adrian Corral.

item.title: Diego Simeone 'close to signing new Atletico Madrid deal... with agent sister in Spain to negotiate extending his stay beyond 2020'
item.description: The 48-year-old has been at Atletico eight years this January making him the longest serving coach in the top European Leagues. His sister Natalia Simeone is in Madrid to formalise an extension.
item.content:encoded:
Atletico Madrid are close to tying Diego Simeone to a new contract according to reports in Argentina.

The 48-year-old has been at Atletico eight years this January, making him the longest-serving coach in the top European leagues.

His sister and agent Natalia Simeone is in Madrid and there are plans to formalise an extension of his current deal that runs out in 2020.


The coach said recently: 'I have spoken to Miguel Angel (Gil Marin, the club's managing director) and it's true that at one point through the season we can talk about extending. I feel content here with more energy than when I first arrived.

'I am stubborn too and I have certain things in my head that I still want to do (at this club).'

Natalia Simeone has indicated in the past that 'sooner or later' Diego will end up in Italy coaching Inter but the signs are that the Atletico coach is closer to committing himself to the club than leaving.

One coach not staying at his current club could be Valencia's Marcelino. The team are out of the Champions League, 18 points off the lead in La Liga, and lost their last-16 cup first-leg against second division Sporting on Tuesday night.

If they lose this weekend against Valladolid the club are expected to fire the coach. Marcelino took on loan Chelsea forward Michy Batshuayi off at half-time in the defeat and wants the Belgian sent back to London with another loan striker coming in.

item.title: Things go from bad to worse for injured player during Brazilian youth cup game as medical cart sent on to help runs over his foot on the pitch
item.description: Sometimes you just know when your luck is not in. In a recent Brazilian cup game, one player had the worst of fortunes, after having his foot run over by the medical cart sent on to help him.
item.content:encoded:
Sometimes you just know when your luck is not in.

In a recent Brazilian cup game, one player experienced the worst of fortunes. After going down injured, a supporting medical cart sent on field to give aid ended up running over his foot.

Trindade came up against Brasileirao giants Flamengo, and it was Bernardo on the unfortunate end of the painful malfunction.

Scroll down for video


The two sides were competing in round two of the pre-season Sao Paulo Junior Soccer Cup 2019.

Bernardo had gone down after receiving a particularly tough challenge, prompting the referee to call over the medics and the use of the driven cart-stretcher in case the player needed to be removed from play.

Upon its approach though, the cart careered far too close to the player, and drove up and over Bernardo's foot as he lay stricken on the floor.

The player could be seen instantly grabbing his foot and shouting in pain, while those around him looked puzzled.

A Copinha é o melhor campeonato do mundo! O carrinho atropelou o jogador 😂😂😂 pic.twitter.com/1Y9o3Q44Tf

— Humor Esportivo (@Humor_Esportivo) January 6, 2019

The nonchalant medical staff appeared unfazed by what had happened, with one even offering a wry smile to the referee after realising the situation.

Eventually, the player was assisted on to the cart, when he remained perched on the edge while it drove from the field.

Bernardo held his head in his hands as he departed. Perhaps out of pain, but most likely embarrassment.

It ended with good news for his team, however, who picked up a 1-0 victory over their rivals.

item.title: Real Madrid 'will not sack Santiago Solari this season'... unless run of bad results ends in a Bernabeu 'bloodbath'
item.description: Santiago Solari finds himself under huge pressure after Sunday's 2-0 defeat by Real Sociedad, a result which left the club fifth in La Liga and 10 points behind rivals and leaders Barcelona.
item.content:encoded:
Real Madrid are planning on sticking with manager Santiago Solari until at least the end of the season - unless there is a 'bloodbath' at the Bernabeu.

The Spaniard finds himself under huge pressure after Sunday's 2-0 defeat by Real Sociedad, a result which left the club fifth in La Liga and 10 points behind rivals and leaders Barcelona.

Solari was only named as the permanent successor to Julen Lopetegui in November, but reports had suggested he could be on his way out of Real already following last weekend's loss.


The 42-year-old, who played for the club between 2000 and 2005, has won 11 of his 15 games in charge, while also overseeing embarrassing 3-0 defeats by Eibar and CSKA Moscow.

However, Spanish radio station Cadena Cope claim that Real president Florentino Perez will keep faith in Solari unless the team's form deteriorates significantly.

According to journalist Paco Gonzalez, only a 'bloodbath' would see Solari sacked before the current campaign comes to an end in May.

It has been a difficult start to 2019 for Solari and his side after they returned from the winter break with a 2-2 draw at Villarreal, then followed it up with Sunday's home defeat against Sociedad.

Sergio Ramos and Co face Leganes in the last 16 of the Copa del Rey on Wednesday night, with Solari promising to attack in the hope of winning silverware this season.

'We will go out looking to win from the first minute and we will have to play similarly to how we did against Melilla (a 10-1 aggregate win in previous round),' he said.

'The Cup is very nice, we need to give it the attention it deserves from the opening minutes of the game.

'Tomorrow (Wednesday) we attack the Cup. We will try to win it, as we try to go out to win every game.

'We are self-critical and we have to be more decisive in the final third of the pitch.

'We're looking to win a title. It's important to be focused from the start and be more convincing in the final third.'

item.title: ‘I could watch this all day’: Chelsea fans go mad for Eden Hazard as he leaves Harry Kane on his backside with lightning quick footwork
item.description: Chelsea fans may not have been able to celebrate the result in their Carabao Cup semi-final first leg meeting with Tottenham, but that didn't stop many rejoicing in the skill of Eden Hazard.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea fans may not have been able to celebrate the result in their Carabao Cup semi-final first leg meeting with Tottenham, but that didn't stop many rejoicing in the incredible skill of star man Eden Hazard.

Spurs won the game 1-0, though Hazard was a driving force throughout and one of few positives for the Blues fans.

A dazzling piece of footwork saw Hazard leave Tottenham's main man Harry Kane slumped on the turf, and supporters quickly took to social media to express their delight and disbelief in equal measure.

Scroll down for video


'Hazard sending Kane back to White Hart lane,' wrote one fan, who shared the short clip of the Belgian leaving his counterpart for dust.

Kane had found himself in a one-on-one position with Hazard on the wing. With the odds stacked against the Spurs man, there was only going to be one winner.

Hazard caressed the ball from one foot to the other and put the England captain on the floor, effortlessly.

'I could watch this all day,' noted another fan, in awe of the winger's skill.

It wasn't the best of evenings for Chelsea though, and many fans quickly noticed Hazard becoming frustrated with his team-mates on the pitch, particularly Marcos Alonso.

The Spaniard tried and failed to find Hazard on several occasions, while a few times passing the ball to the forward when he was in the most compromising of positions.

Speculation around the future of Hazard continues to mount, with the forward endlessly linked with Spanish giants Real Madrid.

item.title: Burton assistant manager Gary Crosby has already got one over Manchester City… watch him score the cheekiest goal of all time back in 1990
item.description: Whatever happens to Burton Albion in their Carabao Cup semi-final, assistant manager Gary Crosby can relax safe in the knowledge he's already got one over Manchester City.
item.content:encoded:
Whatever happens to Burton Albion in their Carabao Cup semi-final, assistant manager Gary Crosby can relax safe in the knowledge he's already got one over Manchester City.

It was 1990 when Crosby scored one of the cheekiest goals ever seen in football, the video footage of which has become a staple of blooper compilations ever since.

Crosby's Nottingham Forest were playing City in a First Division fixture at the City Ground and with the scores goalless a cross was claimed in the air by visiting keeper Andy Dibble.

Scroll down for video


Midfielder Crosby had attempted to reach the ball in but ended up crashing into the advertising boards. As he returned to his feet, he noticed Dibble was holding the ball in just one hand as he assessed his options.

'All I thought as I got up and started running back on to the pitch was: "He's got to have that ball in two hands",' Crosby, 54, recalled to The Guardian this week.

Sneaking up behind the oblivious Dibble, Crosby stooped and headed the ball out of his grasp before tapping it into the unguarded net.

City were naturally furious, with Dibble, his team-mates and his manager Howard Kendall protesting furiously to referee Roger Gifford.

But the goal stood and ultimately proved the only one of the match.

'Whether the referee actually saw it, or to what degree he knew what had happened, I don't know,' added Crosby.

The goal would come to define Dibble's career - somewhat unfairly - more than it did Crosby's but there was no ill-feeling between the pair.

'I can never escape it,' admitted Dibble in an interview some 14 years later but he actually donated his gloves from that day to former Forest keeper Steve Sutton to auction at his testimonial.

'It's the one thing you get remembered for,' said Crosby. 'But I had some fantastic times at Forest.

'Just to play for Brian Clough's side for four or five years, that's my biggest achievement - to be picked by him.

'I wasn't always the favourite but I must have been doing something right.'

Indeed he did. Having joined Clough's Forest from non-league Grantham Town for £20,000 in December 1987, Crosby made 152 appearances and scored 12 goals over seven seasons.

During that time, Forest reached the FA Cup final in 1991 and also made three League Cup finals - they defeated Luton Town in 1989 and Oldham Athletic the following year but lost to Manchester United in 1992.

And in a neat illustration of how some things in football come around full circle, Crosby is now right-hand man to Nigel Clough, Brian's son, at Burton.

He first took the position in October 1998 with the Brewers in the Southern League and they have since risen through the divisions to the third tier, having also featured in the Championship for the two seasons before this one.

item.title: 'He needs to get down and actually do something for this team': AC Milan director Leonardo tells Gonzalo Higuain to 'get to work' amid interest from Chelsea
item.description: AC Milan sporting director Leonardo has told Gonzalo Higuain to focus on the job in hand and ignore interest from Chelsea. Higuain looks set to be reunited with his old boss Maurizio Sarri.
item.content:encoded:
AC Milan sporting director Leonardo has told Gonzalo Higuain to focus on the job in hand and ignore interest from Chelsea.

Maurizio Sarri is desperate for options up front, a plight reinforced by Chelsea's 1-0 Carabao Cup semi-final defeat by Tottenham on Tuesday night, and a deal to take Higuain for the rest of the season is reported to be close.

Sarri managed Higuain at Napoli and, according to reports in Spain, could be reunited with the striker, who is on loan at the San Siro from Juventus, in the next 24 hours.


AC Milan are willing to let Higuain end his loan spell from Juve after only eight months, according to Marca.

However, Leonardo has dismissed the move and has challenged the Argentine to improve at the San Siro.

HIGUAIN UNDER SARRI (2015-16)

Appearances: 54

Goals: 43

Red cards: 1

(all competitions)

HIGUAIN THIS SEASON

Appearances: 20

Goals: 8

Red cards: 1

(all competitions)

'He has to make a decision and take on his share of the responsibility,' Leonardo said at a press conference on Tuesday. 'Not this continual, "yes, no, I'm not sure".

'He had a tough moment, he has to put it behind him and get to work.

'There's no point following rumours and gossip. He is here right now. Seeing as he is here, he needs to get down and actually do something for this team.

'A goal can change things, but if he is to continue here, he needs to take on responsibility.'

Higuain played under Sarri at Napoli in 2015-16, and enjoyed the most productive season of his career with 38 goals in 42 games.

His arrival would likely signal the departure from Chelsea of Alvaro Morata, with Sevilla keen on bringing the misfiring striker back to Spain.

item.title: Eric Garcia is set to cap the perfect 18th birthday by lining up for Manchester City... so who is the starlet plucked from Barcelona and hailed by Pep Guardiola as 'incredible'?
item.description: Eric Garcia should be included in Manchester City’s squad to face Burton Albion on Wednesday. Here, Sportsmail looks at Garcia’s short career and why Pep Guardiola speaks so highly of him.
item.content:encoded:
After making his debut last month, Eric Garcia should be included in Manchester City’s squad to face Burton Albion on Wednesday night.

The central defender is much talked about around the City Football Academy and has impressed those who matter over the last 18 months.

Here, Sportsmail looks at Garcia’s short career and why Pep Guardiola speaks so highly of him.

Has he been at City long?

Garcia, who turned 18 on Wednesday, made the move from Barcelona in the summer of 2017. Back then he was represented by Carles Puyol, but the former captain had to call time on his career as an agent after the backlash Garcia’s switch from La Masia prompted.

Guardiola had become aware of him towards the end of his reign at Bayern Munich and City expended significant resources to lure the defender to the Etihad Stadium.

The City manager has spoken eloquently about the teenager’s maturity and had no problem throwing him in for a debut in the previous Carabao Cup round at Leicester City.

Why has Guardiola been so enthused about his progress?

The summer tour of America was a big one for Garcia. City were without the vast majority of their big hitters, who were recovering from the World Cup, and so the youngsters were afforded a chance.

ERIC GARCIA'S CAREER SO FAR:

Barcelona: 2008-2017

Manchester City: 2017-2018

Spain U17: 2018-2019

Garcia took his with gusto. ‘Eric Garcia is 17 and played like he is 24 or 25,’ said Guardiola after a calming performance during a friendly against Borussia Dortmund.

Here we were watching a defender impart wisdom on those around him during matches, constantly talking and communicating with his team-mates. Garcia is exceptionally vocal for someone so young.

He reads the game superbly and that counteracts his lack of pace, as evidenced at Leicester in December. It is absolutely no stretch to suggest he quietly gave orders to Nicolas Otamendi during that victory on penalties.


A confident guy, then?

Confident yes, but certainly not arrogant. Garcia is quiet, bordering shy. Like Guardiola, he is a keen talker of tactics. He captained every age group at Barcelona and is a statesmanlike figure among his peers.

Garcia has no qualms playing right back and could probably fill in if asked to move into midfield.

Presumably all this has impressed Guardiola?

Correct. The City boss said: ‘He is a guy who has a lot of positional sense. He’s not the strongest one or the fastest but few times do the opponent beat him positionally.

‘He’s able to guide the line. He has good vision, a good pass. I’m very pleased. He didn’t make one mistake. One thing is a friendly and the other is a knockout game. He was incredible.’

So he has a chance on Wednesday in the semi-final?

Guardiola was coy about that in his press conference but Garcia was not selected for the Checkatrade Trophy win at Rochdale, while Philippe Sandler – who made his debut against Rotherham United on Sunday – started.

Garcia instead trained with the first team and will be in the mix. If he starts, it could be alongside Vincent Kompany, who missed out in the FA Cup rout.

‘Eric has been on holiday but we always have an eye on him,’ Guardiola said. ‘In the Carabao Cup and in pre-season he was incredible, in terms of personality, guiding the line, he's so clever. He's a perspective guy to play with us in the future.

‘He's not deserving because of what he's done in the past. All the players from the academy help us but it doesn't mean in the future they are going to play. They have to work hard and pray the manager is going to be kind with them.’

item.title: Dean Elgar to captain South Africa in final Test against Pakistan after Faf du Plessis receives one-match ban
item.description: Dean Elgar has captained South Africa before, against England at Lord's in 2017 when skipper Faf du Plessis returned home for the birth of his child. The Proteas have already won the series.
item.content:encoded:
Dean Elgar will captain South Africa in the third and final Test against Pakistan after regular skipper Faf du Plessis was given a one-match ban for over-rate offences.

Elgar has captained South Africa before, against England at Lord's in 2017 when Du Plessis returned home for the birth of his child.

Du Plessis' absence from the line-up for the final match of the series also makes it likely that 23-year-old batsman Zubayr Hamza will make his Test debut for South Africa.


South Africa won the first two Tests to claim the series and are now seeking a whitewash over Pakistan at the Wanderers in Johannesburg.

Linda Zondi, the CSA National Selection Panel convener, said: 'The appointment of Elgar as stand-in captain is part of our strategy to develop our pool of leaders.

'We have previously used Aiden Markram and Quinton de Kock in this role in ODI matches, and Dean has previously captained the Proteas at Test match level against England at Lord's in 2017.'

item.title: 'We like the player and we want to sign him': Bayern Munich chief lauds Callum Hudson-Odoi as Bundesliga giants turn up the heat in pursuit of Chelsea youngster after £35m bid
item.description: Following Bayern's fourth bid of £35million, which is believed to be Chelsea's asking price, Salihamidzic has lauded the winger and confirmed the Bundesliga giants have a 'great interest' in recruiting him.
item.content:encoded:
Bayern Munich are turning up the heat in their pursuit of Callum Hudson-Odoi after sporting director Hasan Salihamidzic confirmed their interest in signing him.

Following Bayern's fourth bid of £35million, which is believed to be Chelsea's asking price, Salihamidzic has lauded the winger and confirmed the club have a 'great interest' in recruiting him.

'If I have something to announce, I'll do so,' Salihamidzic said on Wednesday at the club's winter training camp in Qatar, after confirming the signing of Benjamin Pavard for next season.


'What I can say: we like the player and take a great interest in signing him. We'll see about the rest.'

When asked about the large price tag which will come with any transfer for the 18-year-old, Salihamidzic added: 'That's the state of the transfer market.

'We must identify those players which can improve us. Callum has unbelievable qualities in the dribbling, he has the pace and skills. We want to sign him.'

Hudson-Odoi has impressed when he has featured for Chelsea this season, including assists for both goals in the 2-0 FA Cup win over Nottingham Forest.

The winger started the Blues' Carabao Cup defeat by Tottenham on Tuesday and certainly enhanced his already burgeoning reputation.

Should he leave he would follow the likes of Jadon Sancho, who plays for Borussia Dortmund, and Reiss Nelson, who is loan at Hoffenheim from Arsenal, by getting the chance to prove his worth in first-team action in the Bundesliga.

Chelsea will be desperate to keep Hudson-Odoi on the books, but the lure of regular senior football and a club so keen to acquire his services could persuade him to make the switch.

item.title: Stoke ready to gamble on Nathan Jones as new boss after agreeing compensation deal with Luton
item.description: Stoke have agreed a compensation package with Luton for their manager. Jones is keen to take the next step in his career after guiding Luton from League Two to second in League One.
item.content:encoded:
Nathan Jones has agreed terms to become Stoke's next manager.

Stoke have finalised a compensation package with Luton and the 45-year-old is currently sorting backroom staff.

Jones is keen to take the next step in his career after guiding Luton from League Two to second in League One.


The move does represent something of a gamble for Stoke's board, with Jones yet to manage in the Championship, but the style he has implemented at Kenilworth Road has won him plenty of admirers.

The Stoke board of chairman Peter Coates, his vice-chairman son John, and chief executive Tony Scholes have been impressed with the way Jones steered Luton to promotion with attractive football.

Technical director Mark Cartwright, a former goalkeeper, also played with Jones at Brighton in the 2000-01 season. Jones did his coaching apprenticeship at the south coast club, and was caretaker manager for two games, before assisting Chris Hughton.

Jones joined Luton in January 2016, guiding the team away from relegation, then won promotion to the third tier last season. His side are in the hunt to go up again and have scored the most goals in League One. An issue for Stoke fans this season has been a lack of goals.

Gary Rowett was sacked by Stoke this week only eight months after they recruited him from Derby.

The club acted amid fan unrest and with promotion slipping from sight. Stoke’s board believe the squad is one of the best in the Championship but they are eight points off the play-offs and lost 2-0 at home to Bristol City before drawing 1-1 at Shrewsbury in the FA Cup.

item.title: Eric Bailly joins Jay-Z’s Roc Nation Sports agency as Manchester United defender is welcomed by Romelu Lukaku and poses with New York Yankees pitcher CC Sabathia
item.description: Manchester United defender Eric Bailly posed alongside New York Yankees pitcher CC Sabathia as the pair swapped signed shirts to welcome the Ivorian to the Roc Nation 'family'.
item.content:encoded:
Eric Bailly is the latest big name to join Jay-Z's management agency Roc Nation Sports.

The Manchester United defender was welcomed by team-mate Romelu Lukaku and Bayern Munich's Jerome Boateng having made the move official.

Bailly posed alongside New York Yankees pitcher CC Sabathia as the pair swapped signed shirts to welcome the Ivorian to the Roc Nation 'family'.


Sabathia's number at the Yankees is No 52 and as a gift for helping welcome Bailly to the agency, he was given a Manchester United shirt of his own with his number on the back.

Bailly is joining a group of footballers at the agency that started with Boateng from Bayern.

Given it is an American company, the bulk of Roc Nation's clients have emerged from American football, basketball and baseball.

Jay-Z's talent stable originated as Roc Nation, an entertainment company, before branching out to Roc Nation Sports and Bailly is the second Premier League addition after team-mate Lukaku.

ROC NATION SPORTS

Roc Nation Sports is the sports management division of Roc Nation, an entertainment company founded by Jay-Z.

The Sports branch was launched in 2013 and proclaims its mission is to aid the careers of athletes on and off the field.

Commercial deals, media relations and 'brand strategy' are all listed as areas Roc Nation Sports helps develop with their clients.

Notable clients include:

Kevin Durant, Dez Bryant, Jerome Boateng, Miguel Cotto, Romelu Lukaku

Writing on his Instagram page, the Manchester United striker welcomed Bailly to the team in a post that read: 'A big welcome to the newest member of the @rocnationsports family. My brother and teammate @ericbailly24 #RocBoys'

Bailly joined United from Villarreal for the 2016-2017 season and quickly became a key part of the side at Old Trafford.

He appeared in 38 games across all competitions that season but has since fallen out of favour during the tenure of the recently sacked Jose Mourinho.

A mix of injuries and suspensions has seen Bailly make just 11 appearances so far this season but he has come back into contention under interim boss Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

United are currently away training in Dubai as they gear up for the biggest test of Solskjaer's reign to date when they travel to Wembley Stadium on Sunday to take on in-form Tottenham.

Bailly will hope the signing with Roc Nation can help see a turnaround of his season as the 24-year-old looks to return to the form that propelled him to quickly become a fans' favourite.

item.title: Move for Chelsea striker Alvaro Morata would be 'very, very complicated', claims Sevilla chief Joaquin Caparros
item.description: A move for Chelsea striker Alvaro Morata would be 'very, very complicated', according to Sevilla sporting director Joaquin Caparros. The Spanish side are set to propose a loan deal.
item.content:encoded:
A move for Chelsea striker Alvaro Morata would be 'very, very complicated', according to Sevilla sporting director Joaquin Caparros.

The Spanish club are interested in bringing the forward back to La Liga as he has struggled to settle at Stamford Bridge.

Having joined Chelsea from Real Madrid for £58million to much fanfare, the 26-year-old has only scored 16 goals since signing in July 2017.


And Caparros would like to offer Morata a way out and a chance to revive his flagging career.

The Sevilla sporting director has met Morata's agent and is ready to propose a loan deal, given his pessimism over a permanent switch.

He told the club's television channel: 'It is true that we have an interest in this player [Morata], but it is a very, very complicated operation.

'The player may want to come here over other options, but it is very complicated. Chelsea are a club who are very difficult to negotiate [with].'

Morata has started 11 games in the Premier League this season, scoring five times. But Maurizio Sarri has preferred to deploy Eden Hazard in the false nine role in recent weeks.

Sevilla are looking to strengthen in the attacking third having loaned out Luis Muriel to Fiorentina.

But there would be no guarantee that Morata would be handed a role in the first team as current strikers Wissam Ben Yedder and Andre Silva have both been in sparkling form so far this season.

item.title: Meet Barcelona's newest wonderkid: Jean-Clair Todibo is tipped as the 'new Raphael Varane' and could form dream partnership with Matthijs de Ligt
item.description: Jean-Clair Todibo is Barcelona’s latest winter signing. Sportsmail looks at the player likened to Raphael Varane in France and who Barcelona hope will one day fill Gerard Pique’s boots.
item.content:encoded:
Jean-Clair Todibo is Barcelona's latest winter signing, with the young French centre-back joining on a free at the end of the season.

The Catalan giants announced the deal on Tuesday. Todibo can also play in midfield and only made his first-team debut for Ligue 1 side Toulouse in August.

Here Sportsmail looks at the player likened to Raphael Varane in France and who Barcelona hope will one day fill Gerard Pique's boots at the Nou Camp.


One for the future then?

Yes operation 'replace Gerard Pique' has passed an important landmark with the signing of 19-year-old Todibo. Pique will be 32 on February 2 and Barcelona can't afford to wait until he retires before building a new defence.

Experience?

He's played 10 games this season for Toulouse with a goal and an assist. The goal was a towering header. He leaps well for a big man.

Shouldn't that be good feet for a big man.

He's 6ft 2ins but he also has excellent spring. And yes he has good feet too. Coming through at Toulouse he has been used as a right-back and a holding midfielder underlying that quality on the ball.

But he hasn't played since November?

He was on a youth-team player's contract but the club wanted to put him on a first-team player's deal. The two sides could not agree and so Toulouse, aware he would now leave for nothing, stopped playing him. There will be no transfer fee for Barcelona to pay.

What's his background?

Born in French Guiana, the French-territory country that borders Brazil, Suriname and the Atlantic ocean, he moved to France and played for his local team Les Lilas before he was picked up by Toulouse FC.

He practised Judo as a youngster and it was on his way to class that he was hit by a car and broke his leg in several places.

He still bears the scars. He was a year out of action and his coach at Toulouse at the time, Dylan Greneche, wondered if Jean-Clair would be able to play sport again.

He made a full recovery and a decade on is set for a move to one of the biggest clubs in the world.

Does this mean they're no longer interested in Matthijs De Ligt?

No. The Ajax centre-back remains the player they really want to build their future defence around.

This is still a major coup for Sporting Director Eric Abidal and another sign that the French market is going to be his speciality. But the young Dutch master is still Barça's No 1 defensive target.

item.title: ‘He deserves better’: Fans think Eden Hazard is ‘fed up’ with Marcus Alonso after Chelsea forward’s exasperated reactions towards team-mate during Carabao Cup defeat at Tottenham
item.description: It didn't take the most eagle-eyed of Chelsea fans to notice the frustration of Eden Hazard in the Carabao Cup semi-final first leg defeat to Tottenham, as one player angered him most of all.
item.content:encoded:
It didn't take the most eagle-eyed of Chelsea fans to notice the obvious frustrations of talisman Eden Hazard in the Carabao Cup semi-final first leg defeat to Tottenham, as one player angered him most of all.

The Belgian winger attempted on several occasions to link up with Marcos Alonso down the flank in order to hurt the Spurs back line, but a series of wayward passes quickly led to the boiling of tempers.

Taking to social media during and after the match, which Tottenham won courtesy of a Harry Kane penalty, fans were quick to identify the errors or Alonso - with some going as far to say they pitied Hazard for having to play alongside such company.


'It's clear to see how fed up Eden Hazard is at playing with Marcos Alonslow. He deserves better,' wrote one fan - poking fun at the Spaniard apparently not being up to the pace.

Another fan poured even more doom and gloom onto the situation, writing: 'Marcos Alonso will be the reason Eden Hazard leaves for Real Madrid.'

'Eden Hazard is well and truly fed up with Marcos Alonso and his aimless passes,' chimed another - while one fan personally felt the need to apologise:

Marcos Alonso will be the reason Eden Hazard leaves for Real Madrid .#CFCpic.twitter.com/ITX8URLnfu

— Edenism (@thechelseaism) January 9, 2019

pic.twitter.com/tskrqr6qaq

— ً (@ChelsFutbol) January 9, 2019

'Hazard is genuinely getting mad at Alonso loool I’m so sorry brother.'

It was just supporters who noticed the ongoing struggles of Hazard, with pundit Jermaine Jenas also weighing in to have his say.

Speaking on BBC Radio 5 Live after the match, Jenas said: 'How good has Hazard been tonight? Demanding the ball, going by players.

'I never thought I would say it, but he's too good for this Chelsea team.'

Chelsea will now host Spurs at Stamford Bridge for the second leg, in hope of overturning the narrow deficit and booking their place in the Carabao Cup final.

item.title: Bayern Munich sign France World Cup-winner Benjamin Pavard on five-year deal... but he will stay at Bundesliga rivals Stuttgart until end of the season
item.description: The 22-year-old plays for Bundesliga rivals Stuttgart and was involved in France's 2018 World Cup final win, a tournament where he also scored a stunning goal in the Round of 16 win over Argentina.
item.content:encoded:
Bayern Munich have reached an agreement to sign French defender Benjamin Pavard, who will join the German champions on a five-year deal from next season, the Bavarian club's sporting director Hasan Salihamidzic said on Wednesday.

The 22-year-old currently plays for Bundesliga rivals VfB Stuttgart and was involved in France's 2018 World Cup final victory over Croatia in Russia, a tournament where he also scored a stunning goal in the last-16 win over Argentina.

'I can announce that we managed to get the services of Benjamin Pavard from July 1, 2019,' Salihamidzic told reporters during a Bayern training camp in Qatar, without giving any financial details of the transfer.


PAVARD'S SEASON

Bundesliga appearances: 14

Pass Success: 84.7 per cent

Aerial Duels won: Average 3 per match

Interceptions: Average 1.9 per match

Clearances: Average 7.4 per match

'He signed a five-year contract.'

The season resumes next week after the annual winter break with Bayern, who have won the last six league titles, in second place, six points behind leaders Borussia Dortmund.

Pavard's Stuttgart, however, are struggling at the bottom end of the table in 16th and play fellow strugglers Mainz next week.

item.title: Yannick Carrasco 'offered to Arsenal' with Belgian winger keen to end one-year spell in China
item.description: Arsenal are in the market for reinforcements in wide areas but with a limited transfer budget available in January, it is believed Carrasco would have to take a pay-cut to get the move over the line.
item.content:encoded:
Yannick Carrasco 'has been offered to Arsenal' as the Belgian looks to cut short his time at Chinese side Dalian Yifang.

Arsenal boss Unai Emery is in the market for reinforcements in wide areas but with a limited transfer budget available in January, it is believed Carrasco would have to take a pay cut to get the move over the line.

According to Belgian journalist Kristof Terreur, Carrasco, who moved to China from Atletico Madrid, is ready to end his stint in Asia and return to the top level of European football.


At 25, many will feel Carrasco still has plenty to offer at the highest level and that a move to Asia came far too early in his career.

Arsenal have favoured wing-backs under Emery but in attacking areas there has been an over-reliance on the likes of Alex Iwobi and Henrikh Mkhitaryan.

Emery has made no secret of his desire to bolster his side in January as he looks to ensure the Gunners earn one of the coveted top four spots come the end of the season.

CARRASCO CV

2012-15: Monaco (103 games, 20 goals)

2015-18: Atletico Madrid (124 games, 23 goals)

2018-PRESENT: Dalian Yifang (26 games, seven goals)

Barcelona's Denis Suarez, who worked with Emery at Sevilla, is believed to be closing in on a move and Carrasco could follow quickly.

There is interest in Carrasco from AC Milan but his £170,000-a-week wages could make a move away from China difficult.

Since moving to China, the Belgian winger has provided seven goals and nine assists in 26 games at Dalian Yifang.

But all has not been well with a training ground bust-up with a team-mate in November suggesting his long-term future lay away from China.

He left Jin Pengxiang needing hospital treatment for a nose injury after the pair scuffled in training as Carrasco publicly apologised and offered £9,000 compensation for the bust-up.

But his European pedigree is not in doubt, evidenced by the stats that show he netted 23 times in 124 matches for Atletico Madrid between 2015 and 2018.

item.title: Bayern Munich are desperate to make Chelsea starlet Callum Hudson-Odoi into the successor to Arjen Robben and Franck Ribery… so will we see another top English talent follow in Jadon Sancho's footsteps and become a hit in Germany?
item.description: KIT HOLDEN: As they prepare to make a £35million swoop for Hudson-Odoi, Bayern Munich will be hoping that the young English winger does not turn out to be the next Renato Sanches.
item.content:encoded:
As they prepare to make a £35million swoop for Callum Hudson-Odoi, Bayern Munich will be hoping that the young English winger does not turn out to be the next Renato Sanches.

On Tuesday, Bayern lodged a fourth bid for Hudson-Odoi, matching Chelsea's asking price and paving the way for the 18-year-old to head to Munich, at the latest in the summer.

If the deal goes ahead, Hudson-Odoi would become one of the most expensive players in Bayern's history, joining for just a few million Euros cheaper than the club's £38m record signing Corentino Tolisso in 2017.


The fee would also exceed the £31m Bayern spent on Portuguese midfielder Renato Sanches a year earlier. Like Hudson-Odoi today, Sanches was just 18 when he moved to Munich, and despite a recent revival under Niko Kovac, he has thus far failed to live up to his price tag.

Bayern, though, have not proven to be once bitten, twice shy. Despite the inherent risk involved when signing such a young player for such a large fee, they have been relentless in their pursuit of Hudson-Odoi.

Anyone who watched the youngster's FA Cup performance against Nottingham Forest, as the Bayern hierarchy reportedly did from the club's training camp in Doha, will be in no doubt about the player's appeal.

Hudson-Odoi grabbed two assists, twice picking out Alvaro Morata with a pinpoint cross from the right wing.

And he impressed again on Tuesday night as he played 79 minutes in Chelsea's loss to Tottenham in the semi-finals of the Carabao Cup.

HUDSON ODOI'S RECORD AT CHELSEA

2017-2018

Four appearances, no goals

(Two Premier League, two FA Cup)

2018-2019

Eight appearances, one goal

(One Premier League, one FA Cup, one League Cup, four Europa League, one Community Shield)

With Franck Ribery set to leave Bayern at the end of the season - and fellow veteran Arjen Robben likely to follow - Bayern are on the lookout for long-term replacements on the wings.

While Serge Gnabry and Kingsley Coman are the natural heirs to Ribery and Robben, the club will not be happy to rely on them alone.

Coman, in particular, is a risk factor after several injuries in recent years. The Frenchman even suggested in a recent interview that another operation could end his career prematurely.

That will have struck fear into the hearts of the Bayern bosses, and sent them scrambling for potential alternatives. In keeping with their general transfer strategy, they are targeting the teenagers. Canadian starlet Alphonso Davies is one example, and Hudson-Odoi may well prove to be another.

'When you look at the astronomical sums that are being paid for ready-made players, it makes sense to scout players early and pay relatively small sums to sign them,' said Bayern coach Kovac when asked about Hudson-Odoi last week.

Knowing they cannot match the likes of Paris Saint-Germain and Real Madrid in terms of spending power, Bayern hope to dominate the market when it comes to signing young players instead.

In recent years, they have had mixed success. While Coman has been a hit, Sanches was initially a flop. Bayern also overlooked Jadon Sancho, who has proven to be one the most explosive signings the Bundesliga has seen in years.

Still smarting from having missed out on Sancho, the club are now determined to beat Borussia Dortmund to the next young superstar, and have decided to look in the same place.

'Hudson-Odoi is from the same year group as Sancho, and that year group has had a lot of success with the England youth teams, so it is normal that we are looking into him,' said Kovac.

There is, nonetheless, a whiff of desperation about the club's unrelenting pursuit of Hudson-Odoi.

Besieged new sporting director Hasan Salihamidzic, widely seen as an ineffective yes-man, is in desperate need of a transfer coup, and he has appeared to have put a lot of his chips on the Chelsea youngster.

Should it come off, the Hudson-Odoi deal may yet prove to be a success for all involved.

Yet the Englishman should be warned. He would not be the first teenager to be disappointed by a move to Bayern, and with Gnabry and Coman around, there is no guarantee of first-team football in Munich.

Perhaps it is a false dichotomy, but it is hard to avoid the notion that Callum Hudson-Odoi could go one of two ways in Germany: he could either become the next Jadon Sancho, or he could turn out to be the next Renato Sanches.

item.title: 'I've always admired Liverpool's history': Alisson reveals reasons behind choosing Jurgen Klopp's side over Chelsea in summer switch
item.description: Liverpool goalkeeper Alisson has shed light on why he chose to join the Reds rather than Chelsea in the summer. The Brazilian was a high profile target for both sides.
item.content:encoded:
Liverpool goalkeeper Alisson has shed light on why he chose to join the Reds rather than Chelsea in the summer.

The Brazilian was a high profile target for both sides but decided to join Jurgen Klopp's team and has impressed ever since.

And Alisson took a number of factors into consideration before signing on the dotted line at Anfield.

'This is a club with five European Cups in their trophy cabinet. I really wanted to be part of that history. I've always admired Liverpool's history,' he said.

He also noted that the uncertainty around Chelsea following the sacking of Antonio Conte counted against the Blues.

'I chose Liverpool for the same reasons I went to Roma when I first left Brazil – I thought this would be the best move for my career.

'Chelsea were changing their manager and not playing in the Champions League,' he added.


ALISSON'S 2018/19 PREMIER LEAGUE STATS:

Games - 21

Minutes - 1890

Clean sheets - 12

Saves - 48

Goals conceded - 10

Maurizio Sarri was made Chelsea boss and the Stamford Bridge club went on to break Alisson's world-record fee for a goalkeeper by signing Kepa Arrizabalaga from Athletic Bilbao for £71m.

Perhaps Alisson will reflect that he made the right choice as Liverpool sit four points clear at the top, with Chelsea 10 points behind in fourth.

The 26-year-old has been a key part of the Reds' success and kept 12 Premier League clean sheets already.

But it is the Champions League that Alisson longs for: 'I came very close to winning the competition with Roma and I'm working hard to make it happen now with Liverpool.

'What's life if not fighting for your dreams? I dream of winning the Champions League,' he added.

item.title: 'He's a really nice boy but a little crazy': Ousmane Dembele's former boss Thomas Tuchel says Frenchman's behaviour was 'never boring'
item.description: Tuchel, who worked with Dembele while in charge of Borussia Dortmund, revealed that life coaching the Frenchman is 'never boring' and that he remains an 'incredible player'.
item.content:encoded:
Thomas Tuchel admits Ousmane Dembele is a 'little crazy' but insists the Barcelona ace remains an 'incredible player'.

The 21-year-old has had moments of controversy since joining the Catalan giants with questions over his attitude, having turned up late for training earlier this season.

Tuchel, who worked with Dembele while in charge of Borussia Dortmund, revealed that life coaching the Frenchman is 'never boring'.


'Ousmane is an incredible player, he's really talented. I could watch his amazing skills in every training session,' the Paris Saint-Germain boss told reporters on Tuesday.

'He's also a great human being. He's a little crazy. He's a really nice boy but a little crazy. He loves to laugh but can also have very serious conversations. It's never boring with him.

'If he's focused enough, he can reach any level. When I talked to him for the very first time, he told me that he wanted to play for Barcelona. That's where he is now.

'It means he can reach any level, but he needs to remain focused and improve each day.'

Dembele has recorded 10 goals and five assists in Barcelona's 23 games across all competitions this season, helping Ernesto Valverde's side to top spot in La Liga.

The young star thrived working under Tuchel during the 2016-17 campaign in a season where he impressed enough to earn his €105million (£94.5m) plus add-ons move to the Nou Camp.

Fans in Barcelona are beginning to see the immense talents Dembele showed in Germany to earn the move and they will be looking for similar heights to be reached in Thursday night's first leg Copa del Rey tie away at Levante.

item.title: Holy guacamole! Super Bowl fans could go without staple snack as fuel shortage may prevent Mexican farmers sending avocado to the US
item.description: Super Bowl fans may have to go without guacamole this year if avocado farmers in Mexico cannot send their fruit to the United States because of a prolonged fuel shortage.
item.content:encoded:
Super Bowl fans may have to go without guacamole this year if avocado farmers in Mexico cannot send their fruit to the United States because of a prolonged fuel shortage.

Like clockwork, Mexican producers ship thousands of tonnes of avocado to the United States in early February every year, where guacamole is a staple living room snack on Super Bowl Sunday.

But the Mexican government's efforts to clamp down on years of mounting fuel theft has a prompted a week-long fuel shortage that has left many states in central and western Mexico high and dry.


Among those states is Michoacan, the country's main avocado grower. Producers there expect to ship 120,000 tonnes for this Super Bowl, 20,000 tonnes more than last year.

'Our three most important weeks of the year are this one and the next two. This is when we ship for Super Bowl week,' said Ramon Paz, spokesman for APEAM, a business association representing Mexican avocado producers and exporters.

'We have from now to January 24, 25 to ship all that volume. If we don't ship it (by then), we can't do so later,' Paz said.

So far, 27,000 tonnes have been sent to the United States for the Super Bowl, which will be held on February 3 in Atlanta, Georgia.

The annual football championship is the most-watched U.S. television broadcast of the year, regularly drawing more than 100 million viewers.

The fuel shortage has not yet affected exports to the United States, but it has begun to hamper transportation in Mexico for workers and harvested avocados, Paz added.

In addition to the Super Bowl, Mexican producers also have to meet commitments with supermarkets and restaurants in the United States.

The crackdown on fuel theft, which has drained billions of dollars from state coffers and is blamed for rising violence in some regions, is leftist President Andres Manuel Lopez Obrador's first major move against criminals and corruption since taking office on December 1. The move risks angering consumers and hurting the economy.

item.title: Fast cars, private jets and courtside NBA seats… 'Money Man' Floyd Mayweather gives fans behind-the-scenes look at a day in his lavish life
item.description: Floyd Mayweather, who recently came out of retirement for a money-spinning $9million exhibition fight in Japan, took to Instagram to document how he spent his Tuesday.
item.content:encoded:
Floyd Mayweather has given fans a glimpse at his extraordinary life away from the ring after travelling in style to watch an NBA match in Los Angeles.

The undefeated 41-year-old, who recently came out of retirement for a money-spinning $9million exhibition fight in Japan, took to Instagram to document how he spent his Tuesday.

Beginning in his Las Vegas mansion, Mayweather introduced the behind-the-scenes clip, saying: 'Today, I'm going to take you into my world. You're going to follow me all day today. Follow me.'

Wearing a £550 blue Versace sweatshirt with matching jogging bottoms, the former multiple weight world champion wanders through his marble home and makes his way outside.

There, Mayweather climbs into his £250,000 Rolls-Royce Cullinan and uses one of the car's impressive features to close the passenger door without touching it.

He then drives off to a local Vegas airport and makes his way through the building and out onto the tarmac, where his private jet is waiting.


Mayweather uses his phone to film as he steps on a TBE ('The Best Ever') mat before boarding 'AirMayweather', which features his TMT ('The Money Team') logo on the outside and on the headrests of the seats.

He gives his 22.5million followers a look inside the plane, which features plush black leather seats, before pointing out the 'first class' area.

Mayweather then settles down for the short flight to Los Angeles, tucking into some lunch while in the air as a member of his team captures his every move.

After a journey of little over an hour, Mayweather steps off his private jet in LA at what appears to be a small private airfield.

He climbs into another high-end car and is driven to the Staples Center, home of the LA Cippers, while R&B music blares in the background.

Mayweather's amateur cameraman makes sure to give fans a close-up of his £145,000 Patek Philippe watch, which was bought with some of his estimated fortune of over $800m.

The former world champion poses with his entourage courtside before taking his seat for the NBA clash between the LA Clippers and the Charlotte Hornets.

And it was the home side who came out on top, with Lou Williams scoring 27 points and laying on 10 assists as the Clippers beat the Hornets for the ninth straight time at the Staples Center.

Montrezl Harrell added 23 points and 11 rebounds, Tobias Harris had 23 and Danilo Gallinari 20 as LA won for a third time in a row.

Mayweather's former rival, Manny Pacquiao, was also in attendance on Tuesday night as he gears up for his next fight against Adrien Broner in Vegas later this month.

Mayweather, meanwhile, has plenty of cash to splash after pocketing $9m for knocking out Japanese kickboxer Tenshin Nasukawa in just over two minutes during an exhibition on New Year's Eve.

The 41-year-old officially remains retired, but could be tempted to return to the ring once again, with rematches against Pacquiao and Conor McGregor both being mooted recently.

Another option for the Money Man is a bout with UFC star Khabib Nurmagomedov, who has spoken extensively about facing Mayweather in 2019.

item.title: Tottenham chairman Daniel Levy 'slaps £225m price tag on Christian Eriksen amid interest from Real Madrid'
item.description: Eriksen will be out of contract in 2020, with Spurs considering letting his contract run down as talks over a new deal continue. The Denmark international is attracting interest from Madrid.
item.content:encoded:
Tottenham chief Daniel Levy has told Real Madrid they can have Danish playmaker Christian Eriksen, provided they're willing to stump up £225million.

Eriksen will be out of contract in 2020, with Spurs considering letting his contract run down as talks over a new deal continue.

The Denmark international is attracting interest from Madrid, who are looking for a long-term replacement for Luka Modric.


But Spanish paper Marca claim they were told by Levy two months ago that they would need to pay a world-record transfer fee to land their man.

It's claimed Madrid would not be willing to match Levy's valuation and Bernabeu chiefs will be patient in their pursuit of the 26-year-old.

They hope the astronomical fee will fall the longer talks over Eriksen's new deal rumble on.

Spurs chairman Levy has relaxed his rule with Eriksen of not allowing players to enter the final two years of their contract, given his importance to Mauricio Pochettino's plans.

But should talks drag on until the summer, Marca report, Levy will have to decide whether to lower his asking price or risk letting Eriksen leave for nothing.

If the Spurs chief continues to play hard-ball, Madrid may look closer to home for Modric's replacement.

Marca claim that though Eriksen is considered the 'ideal' man for the job, 22-year-old Dani Ceballos is the prospect Madrid hope can take on the mantle if they miss out on the Dane.

item.title: 'Maybe he doesn't read anything': Chelsea boss Maurizio Sarri insists Callum Hudson-Odoi has not been distracted by Bayern Munich links
item.description: Hudson-Odoi was handed a start in Chelsea's Carabao Cup semi-final defeat by Tottenham on Tuesday night. Sarri insists the teenager has not been affected by any reports surronding his future,
item.content:encoded:
Callum Hudson-Odoi has not been distracted by talk of a potential move to Bayern Munich, insists Chelsea manager Maurizio Sarri.

The 18-year-old has been linked with a move to the Bundesliga giants, who on Tuesday matched Chelsea's £35million valuation for the forward.

Hudson-Odoi has struggled for game time this season but was handed a start in Chelsea's Carabao Cup semi-final defeat by Tottenham on Tuesday night.


And Sarri insists the teenager has not been affected by any reports surrounding his future.

'Odoi in the last week has been very normal. I have seen him every day in training, he has been really very normal,' he said.

'He is improving, in the last match he played very well and also today I think a very good match.

'He played like a player of 25 or 26 years, I think – very good match of application, very good in the defensive phase, very, very good.

'He was completely normal in this period. I don't know, maybe he doesn't read anything.'

Chelsea were beaten 1-0 by rivals Tottenham at Wembley thanks to Harry Kane's penalty, awarded after the officials consulted VAR.

Sarri's side now must overturn that deficit in the second leg at Stamford Bridge later this month to stay in the hunt for early silverware this season.

'I think we deserved more. In this match we played better than the opponents,' Sarri said.

'We were in control of the match, we defended very well against opponents who are very dangerous in the offensive phase, I think we deserved more.'

item.title: Australia ring the changes after India defeat with Will Pucovski in line for his debut and Shaun Marsh among four culled for two-Test Sri Lanka series
item.description: Batsmen Aaron Finch, Shaun Marsh, Peter Handscomb and all-rounder Mitchell Marsh were all dropped from the squad that lost a home Test series against India for the first time.
item.content:encoded:
Top-order batsmen Matt Renshaw and Joe Burns have been recalled, while the highly rated Will Pucovski appears set to win his first cap as the Australia selectors culled four underperforming players for the two-Test home series against Sri Lanka.

Batsmen Aaron Finch, Shaun Marsh, Peter Handscomb and all-rounder Mitchell Marsh were all dropped from the squad that lost a home Test series against India for the first time.

Virat Kohli's side took the four-match series 2-1 and would likely have won the final Test in Sydney had rain not intervened over the last two days as the contest, in which Australia were made to follow-on, ended in a damp draw on Monday.


Australia's top order failed to perform against India's versatile attack and selection panel head Trevor Hohns admitted that the side needed to be shaken up for the Sri Lanka series, which start in Brisbane on January 24.

AUSTRALIA SQUAD TO FACE SRI LANKA

Marcus Harris, Joe Burns, Matthew Renshaw, Usman Khawaja, Travis Head, Will Pucovksi, Marnus Labuschagne, Tim Paine (c), Pat Cummins, Mitchell Starc, Nathan Lyon, Josh Hazlewood, Peter Siddle

'Ultimately Aaron, Peter, Shaun and Mitch have not produced the performances expected of them with the bat at the Test level,' Hohns told reporters on Wednesday. 'They have been given good opportunity, but have not produced the scores we need.

'All four are very good players, and the door is by no means closed for them to return to play Test cricket for Australia.

'The challenge now is for them to make runs for Australia in the upcoming ODIs (one-dayers against India), and then to go back to the Sheffield Shield (domestic first-class cricket) and make more runs.'

Opener Renshaw last played a Test on the tour of South Africa last March, when he was a late call-up after Cameron Bancroft and David Warner were stood down for their role in a ball-tampering scandal.

Burns was also called into the side for the final Test in South Africa and had been scoring heavily for Queensland in the Sheffield Shield.

Pucovski has played just eight first-class matches but scored 243 for Victoria earlier this season before the 20-year-old opted to take a break from the game to receive treatment for a mental health-related illness.

'Will Pucovski is an exciting young player who is making his mark in the Sheffield Shield,' Hohns added. 'He is another player with a track record of making centuries. We look forward to him joining the squad.'

item.title: World No 1 Simona Halep beaten in straight sets by Ashleigh Barty on her return from lengthy injury lay-off
item.description: It was Halep's first match since October after a lengthy lay-off due to a herniated disc in her back. Halep won last year's French Open and lost to Caroline Wozniacki in the Australian Open final.
item.content:encoded:
Ashleigh Barty broke Simona Halep's serve in the final game of the match to beat the No 1-ranked Halep 6-4, 6-4 in a second-round match on Wednesday at the Sydney International.

It was Halep's first match since October after a lengthy lay-off due to a herniated disc in her back. Halep won last year's French Open and lost to Caroline Wozniacki in the Australian Open final.

The Australian served five aces, no double-faults and broke Halep three times to reverse two previous losses to Halep last August.


'I finally learned my lesson,' Barty said. 'She gave me a belting in Montreal. I learned a little bit more in Cincinnati, but today I knuckled down and really thought about it and really gave myself a chance.

'The biggest thing, I believed that I could I win. We're both out here on the same court. Just very happy I was able to come out and execute.'

The 27-year-old Halep will be at the Australian Open next week in Melbourne without a coach after parting ways with Australian mentor Darren Cahill, who can longer commit to Halep due to family reasons. Cahill had coached Halep for four years.

In a first-round match, 10th-seeded Elise Mertens beat qualifier Katerina Siniakova 7-6 (4), 2-6, 6-2.

In the second round, Timea Bacsinszky defeated Samantha Stosur 5-7, 6-4, 6-3.

In men's play, Alex de Minaur beat American qualifier Reilly Opelka 6-4 7-6 (4) in a match suspended by rain after just one game on Tuesday night to advance to the quarter-finals against fellow Australian Jordan Thompson.

'I think I got lucky today. Reilly's an incredibly tough opponent,' de Minaur said. 'I took care of my chances. I would have loved to get the break in the second. I had a couple of chances, but I did well to focus on my serve and I'm glad things went my way today.'

In other second-round matches, third-seeded Diego Schwartzman beat qualifier Guillermo Garcia-Lopez 6-2, 6-3 and Yoshihito Nishioka defeated Andrey Rublev 6-3, 6-1.

item.title: Cameron Norrie reaches ASB Classic quarter-finals with victory over Joao Sousa as Dan Evans' bid to make the Australian Open begins with a win
item.description: The 23-year-old saved all six break points faced to battle past his Portuguese opponent 7-6 (5), 6-4. Elsewhere, Evans defeated Rogerio Dutra Da Silva in the first round of Australian Open qualifying.
item.content:encoded:
Britain's Cameron Norrie secured his spot in the quarter-finals of the ASB Classic in Auckland with a straight-sets win over Joao Sousa.

The 23-year-old saved all six break points faced to battle past his Portuguese opponent 7-6 (5), 6-4 in an hour and 35 minutes.

A closely-fought first set saw Norrie edge ahead in the tiebreak, before he went on to convert his first and only break point of the match in the third game of the second set.


The single break of serve was enough for the British wild card to claim the victory and set up a meeting with American Taylor Fritz in the last eight.

Fritz, ranked 50 in the world, had earlier dismissed top seed John Isner 7-6 (3), 7-6 (5).

Elsewhere, Dan Evans defeated Brazil's Rogerio Dutra Da Silva in the first round of the Australian Open qualifying.

The 28-year-old needed just under an hour to dismiss his opponent 6-2, 6-3 and set up a meeting with Jurij Rodionov in the second qualifying round.

Evans, currently ranked 190 in the world, broke twice in the first set and once in the second to wrap up the victory.

Fellow Briton Jay Clarke had less success, falling 6-2, 6-3 to Italy's Lorenzo Sonego in the opening round of qualifying.

The 20-year-old, ranked 237 in the world, lost his serve twice as his opponent wrapped up the first set in just over half an hour.

Clarke looked to be fighting back in the second, breaking Sonego in the opening game, but could not hold on to the lead and was immediately broken back.
