item.title: Lionel Messi puts Real Madrid to shame... Barcelona legend has contributed to the same number of La Liga goals as fierce rivals this season
item.description: Lionel Messi is putting the entire Real Madrid strikeforce to shame in La Liga this season. The Barcelona forward has netted 16 times and provided 10 assists.
item.content:encoded:
Lionel Messi is putting the entire Real Madrid strikeforce to shame in La Liga this season.

The Barcelona forward has netted 16 times and provided 10 assists for his team-mates as he continues to dominate Spanish football.

A combined total of 26 goal contributions is the same number as their fierce rivals Real have scored all season.

Santiago Solari's side are struggling and the statistics damn them, with Messi's numbers illustrating the difference between the old foes.

Karim Benzema is the leading scorer with seven and Gareth Bale is level with Sergio Ramos on four.

But Real have struggled to hit the target on a regular basis and only have a goal difference of +3 despite the vast array of attacking talent in the squad.


Messi, who controversially finished fifth in the votes for the Ballon d'Or, has excelled and led the Spanish champions to the top of the league, 10 points clear of Real in fifth.

Solari's side suffered a 2-0 defeat at the Bernabeu on Sunday, a sixth La Liga loss of the hugely disappointing campaign.

Perhaps the arrival of Brahim Diaz from Manchester City will kick start the Champions League holders' season into life and out of Messi's shadow.

item.title: Brahim Diaz is latest Manchester City kid to leave for multi-millions after his move to Real Madrid... Pep Guardiola's side have sold players with just 33 starts for £137m over years
item.description: Even the most committed of Manchester City fans would not have pegged Brahim Diaz as a £22million player. But that is the way the market have gone, and City are kings of using it.
item.content:encoded:
Even the most committed of Manchester City fans would not have pegged Brahim Diaz as a £22million player.

But that is the way the market has gone, and he sealed a massive move to Real Madrid on Monday after months of speculation that he would trade the Etihad Stadium for the Santiago Bernabeu.

Diaz made just four starts for City before Real took the plunge on the huge move to bring him back to his native Spain.

City have an incredible record for doing just this, maximising the amount received from the players they have developed at their academy.

Through a combination of loans, pre-season appearances and the rare start, other clubs look at the talent just below the starting XI at City and decide to make moves.

Just how much have City made over the last few years from kids? Sportsmail has taken a look at a group of players with just 33 starts between them and how much City have made from their sales...


Kelechi Iheanacho (Leicester) - £25.4m (20 starts)

Easily the most heavily used of the players City have brought in as kids and then sold on. Kelechi Iheanacho was picked by Pep Guardiola for a Manchester derby, scored and assisted and, at one stage, had a better record than Sergio Aguero for goals per minutes played. Hit 10 Premier League goals before he turned 20 but then moved on to Leicester in August 2017.

Brahim Diaz (Real Madrid) - £22m (4 starts)

Bought for just £200,000 from Malaga as a 16-year-old, he moved to Real Madrid on Monday as a near-£20m player at the age of 19. Made few appearances for City, primarily impressing in pre-season. Received a winner's medal last season and appeared in the Community Shield this campaign. Also scored twice against Fulham this season before sale ramped up. Played 49 minutes of Premier League football for City.

Angus Gunn (Southampton) - £13.5m (0 starts)

The son of Norwich City legend Bryan Gunn. Joined City in 2011 from the Canaries but made his name at Carrow Road last season, with a loan spell that saw him appear in every league game. Coveted this summer, Southampton made an offer for him and City sold him on without a single competitive appearance.

Enes Unal (Villarreal) - £12.7m (0 starts)

Made a very early impact in his native Turkey, scoring after three minutes of his league debut and making 34 appearances at Bursaspor. City snapped him up for £2million. Loan spells followed but no appearances for City. After a run of 18 goals in 32 games for Twente, Villarreal snapped him up.

Jason Denayer (Lyon) - £9.9m (0 starts)

Impressed for City's youth teams before moving out on loan. Did well for Celtic alongside Virgil van Dijk and won honours. Spent time with Sunderland in the middle of two loan spells at Galatasaray, the second of which convinced Lyon to sign him permanently.

Jadon Sancho (Borussia Dortmund) - £9.1m (0 starts)

Possibly the one City will regret letting leave, although Sancho stopped turning up for training and they had to move him on. Has been sublime this season for Dortmund, leading the way for young players across Europe. Now has full England honours and must be a target for every top team worldwide en route to the Bundesliga crown.

Pablo Maffeo (Stuttgart) - £8.8m (3 starts)

Picked up from Spain by City. Spent two years in the academy but was brought into the first-team by Manuel Pellegrini, making three starts in total across cup competitions and Europe. A pair of loan spells at Girona followed before he moved to Stuttgart this summer.

Rony Lopes (Monaco) - £8.8m (3 starts)

Moved to City from Benfica after coming to Europe from Brazil. Lopes made a few cup appearances for City, starting against West Ham in a League Cup semi-final while providing two assists. He was loaned to Lyon in the 2014-15 season before being snapped up by Monaco in the summer of 2015.

Karim Rekik (Marseille) - £7.5m (1 start)

Came to City in 2011 from Feyenoord. Was loaned out within a year to Portsmouth, then Blackburn, before a two-year spell at PSV. A run of 54 appearances in Eindhoven convinced Marseille to snap him up. The defender now plays for Hertha Berlin.

Angelino (PSV) - £5.6m (1 start)

A left-back signed from Spain. Made his debut against Aston Villa away in the FA Cup in January 2016 following a loan spell at New York City. Then went to Girona, Mallorca and Breda before PSV signed him in the summer.

Olivier Ntcham (Celtic) - £5.5m (0 starts)

Ntcham refused to sign a new contract at boyhood club Le Havre and instead moved to City for €1m. Spent three years at youth level before joining Genoa on a two year loan. Scored three times in 37 appearances there before Celtic signed him in summer 2017. He has become a key player in Scotland.

Seko Fofana (Udinese) - £4.2m (0 starts)

City snapped up Fofana from Lorient. He had a year with the academy before he moved to Fulham. Then joined Bastia on loan following two appearances in pre-season for City. Moved on to Udinese and has established himself as a fine midfielder in Serie A.

Bersant Celina (Swansea) - £3.8m (1 start)

At one point, seemed like Bersant Celina could make the breakthrough at City. He featured in squads under Manuel Pellegrini and eventually played in an FA Cup match against Norwich in January 2016. Had loans at Twente and Ipswich before Swansea brought him in permanently in the summer.

Total - £136.8m

item.title: Chelsea v Tottenham in Carabao Cup second leg moved to a THURSDAY with dates finally confirmed
item.description: Chelsea will host Tottenham on Thursday, January 24 in the second leg of their Carabao Cup semi-final, the EFL have confirmed. Burton Albion and Manchester City will play on January 23.
item.content:encoded:
Chelsea will host Tottenham on Thursday, January 24 in the second leg of their Carabao Cup semi-final, the EFL have confirmed.

The second semi-final between Burton Albion and Manchester City at the Pirelli Stadium will be held the day before on Wednesday, January 23.

The first legs of the League Cup last four kick-off on Tuesday night when Maurizio Sarri's side travel to Wembley to face Spurs.


League One side Burton travel to the Etihad Stadium on Wednesday evening following victories over Shrewsbury, Aston Villa, Burnley, Nottingham Forest and Middlesbrough in the previous rounds.

The EFL announced the second-leg dates ahead of the first-leg ties after having to fit the matches in with the Premier League schedule.

City and Tottenham both play televised league matches on Sunday, January 20 and so could not play their League Cup clashes on Tuesday, January 22.

CARABAO CUP SEMIS

Jan 8: Tottenham v Chelsea (8pm)

Jan 9: Man City v Burton (7.45pm)

Jan 23: Burton v Man City (7.45pm)

Jan 24: Chelsea v Tottenham (7.45pm)

While Pep Guardiola's side also face Newcastle in the top flight on Tuesday, January 29, which will also be televised.

Chelsea's Premier League clash at Bournemouth has been pushed back 24 hours to Wednesday, January 30. The date of their Carabao Cup second leg as well as their involvement in the FA Cup fourth round has led to the change.

The Blues beat Liverpool, Derby and Bournemouth to reach the semi-final, having last won the trophy in 2015 under Jose Mourinho.

John Terry and Diego Costa scored in the 2-0 victory over Tottenham, who are still awaiting a first trophy under Mauricio Pochettino.

Spurs had to overcome Watford 4-2 on penalties after a 2-2 draw in the first round, before beating West Ham 3-1 and Arsenal 2-0 to advance to the semi-finals.

City, the 2018 winners, saw off Oxford United, Fulham and Leicester - on penalties - to set up their last-four tie.

The use of video assistant referees (VAR) is set to continue in the competition with the final taking place on Sunday, February 24.

item.title: Manchester City youngster Phil Foden celebrates scoring in win over Rotherham with trip to Five Guys
item.description: Manchester City's convincing 7-0 win over Rotherham in the FA Cup was certainly cause for celebration. While some might have ventured out for lavish meals, Phil Foden went to Five Guys.
item.content:encoded:
Manchester City's convincing 7-0 win over Rotherham in the FA Cup on Sunday was certainly cause for celebration.

While some might have ventured out for lavish meals on Monday, 18-year-old Phil Foden made a dash to the Trafford Centre.

The playmaker, who scored in the third-round victory, opted for the fast-food chain Five Guys and was pictured mulling over which burger-and-fries combo to choose from.


And he could potentially have bigger decisions than that to make in the near future. While he was making his way to the Trafford Centre, his former team-mate Brahim Diaz was being unveiled as a £22million Real Madrid signing at the Bernabeu.

Diaz followed the path of Jadon Sancho, who is now pulling up trees at Borussia Dortmund and has gained international recognition after being called up to Gareth Southgate's England squad.

Foden, meanwhile, has played just 91 minutes of Premier League football this season — he has the likes of Raheem Sterling, David Silva, Bernardo Silva and Kevin De Bruyne in front of him — and has a fight on his hands to gain a regular first-team spot.

FODEN STATS 18-19

Appearances: 16

Goals: 2

Assists: 2

Bookings: 1

But the midfielder, who signed a new six-year contract last month, has no interest in taking the same route as Diaz and is determined to establish himself at the Etihad.

'It's up to them really,' he said. 'They have gone their separate ways and everyone has their own plan in what they want to do, so fair play to them.

'Everyone is different, and I see myself playing here. It's up to them, really. It shows the strength of the squad we have here, how good the players are. It is difficult to get in, but we all try our best.

'I just need to keep pushing, do my best in the games and take opportunities when they come.

'We've got the best set of players and the best staff so I'm in the right position. I'm learning off them every day, so I couldn't be in a better place.

'It's brilliant to play alongside players like Kevin De Bruyne. You just learn from the best.'

item.title: Paul Dummett joins Jonjo Shelvey in Barcelona as Newcastle pair seek specialist treatment to solve long-term injury problems
item.description: EXCLUSIVE BY CRAIG HOPE: Dummett has been plagued by hamstring issues - he tore the muscle on the opening day - and he missed a month during this campaign after suffering a strain.
item.content:encoded:
Newcastle defender Paul Dummett has joined team-mate Jonjo Shelvey in Barcelona as they seek answers to lingering injury problems.

Dummett has been plagued by hamstring issues since the start of last season - he tore the muscle on the opening day - and he missed a month during this campaign after suffering a strain playing for Wales.

The 27-year-old is hoping that a Spanish specialist can help find a solution to an issue that remains a constant worry for the player and manager Rafa Benitez.


Sportsmail understands physio Sean Beech has travelled with the players to oversee their treatment and both could still be involved when Newcastle travel to Chelsea on Saturday.

Dummett has emerged as United's most consistent defender under Benitez and is the only recognised left back on the books at St James' Park.

The boss would like to bring in another player in that position this month - especially given the fear over Dummett's hamstrings - but progress has been slow on the transfer front.

He would also like to add another midfielder with Shelvey's thigh complaint having limited him to just eight Premier League starts this season.

We revealed on Monday that the playmaker has headed to Barcelona in search of a solution to his injury.

Both Shelvey and Dummett are automatic starters and their fitness could be key to Newcastle's survival chances.

item.title: Paul Merson claims Arsenal are 20 YEARS AWAY from winning the Premier League and that they need seven players to compete
item.description: Arsenal legend Paul Merson, who came through the ranks at the club and won two First Division titles, believes the current crop are nowhere near the league's best.
item.content:encoded:
Paul Merson has taken a swipe at Arsenal's chances of winning the Premier League, claiming they are '20 years' away from the title.

Unai Emery replaced Arsene Wenger last summer, ending the Frenchman's 22-year reign in charge, but the Gunners are still only fifth in the table this season, 13 points behind leaders Liverpool with 17 games remaining.

Club legend Merson, who came through the ranks at Arsenal and won two First Division titles, believes the current crop are nowhere near the league's best and has claimed they need seven new players to even mount a title challenge.


Asked how far his former club are away from lifting the Premier League trophy, Merson told Sky Sports: 'What do you think? 20 years.

'They're a million miles away at the moment and the way it is going right now they probably need seven players to compete.

'I don't see them winning again for a long, long time.'

Arsenal last won the Premier League title during the 2003-04 campaign, when Wenger's side managed to go the whole season unbeaten.

The Gunners have already lost four top-flight matches this season, and Merson insists some of their recent recruitment decisions will have a big impact on their future success.

Aaron Ramsey will leave on a free transfer when his contract expires at the end of the season, while Mesut Ozil has fallen out of favour under Emery despite being on a £350,000-a-week contract until the summer of 2021.

'Letting (Aaron) Ramsey leave is just bad, bad club management isn't it,' Merson added.

'To let player contracts run out in this day and age for how much these players go for and how much they're worth is criminal.

'To let him leave the club and walk away for free, somebody in his prime leaving for nothing, it's a football crime.

'Now they have got to replace him and that will cost money but until the (Mesut) Ozil problem gets sorted out they are going to find it difficult to bring in players.

'Because if they bid £50-60million for someone, the first thing the player will say is well I want what Ozil is getting.

'And when the club says you aren't getting that then the player will just say "well I'm not coming then". And that is what happened with Ramsey.'

item.title: ‘How come Wolves controlled the ball and won then?’: Fans mock Jurgen Klopp after he blames the wind for Liverpool’s FA Cup defeat
item.description: Jurgen Klopp has come in for criticism on Twitter after suggesting strong winds made it difficult for Liverpool in their 2-1 FA Cup defeat by Wolves.
item.content:encoded:
Jurgen Klopp has come in for criticism on Twitter after suggesting strong winds made it difficult for Liverpool in their 2-1 FA Cup defeat by Wolves.

Plenty took to social media to mock the Reds manager for what they perceived to be a weak excuse.

Klopp made sweeping changes to the team and included a number of inexperienced teenagers in the line-up.

Ruben Neves blasted the winner after Divock Origi cancelled out Raul Jimenez's opener and Klopp lamented his side's inability to dictate play.

He said: 'The wind didn't help, everybody on the pitch struggled to control, first touches were tough. We lost a lot of balls.'

One Twitter user condemned Klopp's assessment as a 'childish excuse', with a frustrated Manchester United supporter saying the German 'always' had an excuse for losing.

Some chimed in referencing other times Klopp has argued that conditions made it more difficult.


One user said he'd blamed the sun last season and another added that he cited long grass on the Etihad Stadium pitch for the 2-1 defeat by Manchester City, though there is no evidence to support this.

Klopp confessed that he has seen his young talents fare better in training than they did under the bright lights on Monday.

'We are not here to be the new world record holder for youngest team, they are good enough,' he added.

'They train with us, 10 vs 10 and believe me they play much better than they did tonight.

'These boys all played because they are good enough. They did well but they can do much better.'
